Scaling and Calculation: Measuring the Microscopic World

Master the essential microscopy calculations that allow us to determine the true size of cells and organelles from magnified images‚Äîa critical HSC practical skill.

üìè

üéØ LEARNING INTENTIONS

  • Students can calculate total magnification of a compound microscope
  • Students can measure field of view diameter at different magnifications
  • Students can calculate actual size of specimens from images
  • Students can convert between units (mm, Œºm, nm)
  • Students can apply the magnification formula in various contexts

üîó KEY CONNECTIONS

  • Prior: Microscope types, resolution, common cell sizes
  • Future: Biological drawing, wet-mount preparation
  • Real World: Medical diagnostics, forensics, research microscopy
  • HSC Skills: Processing data, mathematical calculations

‚úÖ SUCCESS CRITERIA

  • I can calculate total magnification correctly
  • I can measure and calculate field of view diameter
  • I can use the magnification formula to find actual size
  • I can convert between mm, Œºm, and nm confidently
  • I can show all working with correct units
üî¢

Unit Conversions: The Language of Microscopy

Microscopic structures range from millimetres to nanometres. Understanding unit conversions is essential for accurate measurements.

UnitSymbolMetresConversionTypical Use
Millimetremm10‚Åª¬≥ m1 mm = 1000 ŒºmField of view, large specimens
MicrometreŒºm10‚Åª‚Å∂ m1 Œºm = 1000 nmCells, organelles, bacteria
Nanometrenm10‚Åª‚Åπ m1 nm = 0.001 ŒºmViruses, molecules, proteins
üí° Memory Aid: Each step down multiplies by 1000: mm ‚Üí Œºm ‚Üí nm. Going up, divide by 1000.

Conversion Examples

üìù Example 1: mm to Œºm

Question: A field of view is 4.5 mm. Express in Œºm.

Solution: 4.5 mm √ó 1000 = 4500 Œºm

üìù Example 2: Œºm to nm

Question: A bacterium measures 2.5 Œºm. Express in nm.

Solution: 2.5 Œºm √ó 1000 = 2500 nm

üìù Example 3: nm to Œºm

Question: A ribosome is 25 nm. Express in Œºm.

Solution: 25 nm √∑ 1000 = 0.025 Œºm

‚ö†Ô∏è Common Mistake: Always convert units before calculating. If the answer should be in Œºm, convert everything to Œºm first.
üî¨

Calculating Total Magnification

A compound light microscope uses two lens systems. Total magnification is the product of eyepiece and objective magnifications.

Formula: Total Magnification = Eyepiece √ó Objective

Where:
‚Ä¢ Eyepiece is usually 10√ó
‚Ä¢ Objective varies: 4√ó, 10√ó, 40√ó, 100√ó

üìù Example 4: Total Magnification

Question: 10√ó eyepiece and 40√ó objective. Total magnification?

Solution: 10 √ó 40 = 400√ó

EyepieceObjectiveTotalUse
10√ó4√ó40√óScanning: locating specimen
10√ó10√ó100√óLow power: cells and tissues
10√ó40√ó400√óHigh power: detailed observation (HSC)
10√ó100√ó1000√óOil immersion: bacteria, blood
‚≠ï

Field of View (FOV)

The field of view (FOV) is the diameter of the circular area visible through the microscope. As magnification increases, FOV decreases.

üí° Key Concept: FOV and magnification have an inverse relationship. Double the magnification ‚Üí halve the FOV.

Measuring Field of View

üìè

STEP 1: MEASURE AT LOW POWER

Place ruler on stage. Focus at lowest magnification. Count mm across diameter.

Example: At 40√ó, FOV = 4.5 mm.
‚Üì
üî¢

STEP 2: CALCULATE AT HIGHER POWERS

Use magnification ratio: FOVhigh = FOVlow √ó (Maglow √∑ Maghigh)

‚Üì
üîÑ

STEP 3: CONVERT UNITS

Convert to Œºm if measuring cells: 1 mm = 1000 Œºm.

üìù Example 5: FOV at Higher Magnification

Question: FOV at 40√ó is 4.5 mm. What is FOV at 400√ó?

Solution:

FOV400√ó = 4.5 mm √ó (40 √∑ 400) = 4.5 √ó 0.1 = 0.45 mm = 450 Œºm
üìê

The Magnification Formula

The magnification formula is the most important calculation in microscopy. It relates image size, actual size, and magnification.

The Magnification Triangle:

M = I √∑ A     I = M √ó A     A = I √∑ M

Where:
‚Ä¢ M = Magnification (no units, or √ó)
‚Ä¢ I = Image size (measured from micrograph)
‚Ä¢ A = Actual size (real size of specimen)

Golden Rule: Always use the same units for I and A!

üìù Example 6: Finding Actual Size

Question: A micrograph at 400√ó shows a cell measuring 20 mm across. What is the actual size in Œºm?

Solution:

Step 1: Convert image size to Œºm: 20 mm = 20,000 Œºm.
Step 2: Use A = I √∑ M.
Step 3: A = 20,000 Œºm √∑ 400 = 50 Œºm.

üìù Example 7: Finding Magnification

Question: An onion cell is 300 Œºm long. In a micrograph it measures 60 mm. What is the magnification?

Solution:

Step 1: Convert to same units: 60 mm = 60,000 Œºm.
Step 2: Use M = I √∑ A.
Step 3: M = 60,000 √∑ 300 = 200√ó.

üìù Example 8: Finding Image Size

Question: A red blood cell is 7 Œºm in diameter. At 1000√ó magnification, how large will it appear in mm?

Solution:

Step 1: Use I = M √ó A.
Step 2: I = 1000 √ó 7 Œºm = 7000 Œºm.
Step 3: Convert to mm: 7000 Œºm = 7 mm.

Unit Conversions

  • 1 mm = 1000 Œºm
  • 1 Œºm = 1000 nm
  • mm ‚Üí Œºm: √ó 1000
  • Œºm ‚Üí nm: √ó 1000
  • nm ‚Üí Œºm: √∑ 1000
  • Œºm ‚Üí mm: √∑ 1000

Total Magnification

  • Total Mag = Eyepiece √ó Objective
  • Common: 10√ó eyepiece
  • Objectives: 4√ó, 10√ó, 40√ó, 100√ó
  • 40√ó objective = 400√ó total

Field of View

  • FOV decreases as magnification increases
  • FOVhigh = FOVlow √ó (Maglow √∑ Maghigh)
  • Measure at low power, calculate for high

Magnification Formula

  • M = I √∑ A (Magnification)
  • I = M √ó A (Image size)
  • A = I √∑ M (Actual size)
  • Always use same units!

mcq.question: A microscope has a 10√ó eyepiece and a 40√ó objective. What is the total magnification?

mcq.explanation: Magnification = Image size √∑ Actual size (M = I √∑ A).

saq.question: A student observes a plant cell using a microscope with a 10√ó eyepiece and a 40√ó objective lens. The cell appears to measure 16 mm across in the field of view. Calculate the actual size of the cell in micrometres. Show all working.
markingCriteria: 1 mark: Convert image size to Œºm (16,000 Œºm) OR set up formula correctly
1 mark: Correct final answer (40 Œºm) with units
saq.modelAnswer: Total magnification = 10 √ó 40 = 400√ó. Image size = 16 mm = 16,000 Œºm. Actual size = Image size √∑ Magnification = 16,000 Œºm √∑ 400 = 40 Œºm.

saq.question: The field of view at 100√ó magnification is measured as 2 mm. Calculate the field of view at 400√ó magnification. Express your answer in micrometres.
markingCriteria: 1 mark: Set up FOV formula correctly
1 mark: Calculate FOV in mm (0.5 mm)
1 mark: Convert to Œºm (500 Œºm) with correct units
saq.modelAnswer: FOV at 400√ó = FOV at 100√ó √ó (100√∑400) = 2 mm √ó 0.25 = 0.5 mm. Converting: 0.5 mm √ó 1000 = 500 Œºm.

saq.question: A red blood cell has an actual diameter of 7 Œºm. Calculate how large it would appear in a micrograph taken at 500√ó magnification. Express your answer in millimetres.
markingCriteria: 1 mark: Set up formula I = M √ó A correctly
1 mark: Calculate image size in Œºm (3500 Œºm)
1 mark: Convert to mm (3.5 mm) with correct units
saq.modelAnswer: Image size = Magnification √ó Actual size = 500 √ó 7 Œºm = 3500 Œºm. Converting: 3500 Œºm √∑ 1000 = 3.5 mm.
